abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey satisfactory project
            outcomes, likely sustainability, with only modest
            institutional development impacts. Among the lessons
            learned, it is suggested that while the focus was mainly on
            maintenance, and rehabilitation works - in principle a sound
            response to the crisis at the time, to seek the highest rate
            of return - however in practice, this caused works which
            were viable (but with lower rates of return) to be dropped.
            The economy would have been better served by a balanced
            program, one that retained a small high priority
            congestion-relief program, with high returns. Furthermore,
            current practices in the road sector hinder incentives to
            achieve good quality. Thus it is recommended that
            output-based, and performance-based contracts, be
            implemented on a trial basis for maintenance, and
            rehabilitation works. And, improvements to the financing of
            the road sector, needs to focus both on savings in
            implementation costs, and on relating revenues more closely
            to costs recovery incurred through road usage. Other lessons
            address: a) management and information technology, i.e.,
            more affordability, and sustainability of surveys, accuracy
            and reliability in a decentralized environment, and,
            conversion of the database to a geo-referenced location
            referencing system; b) programmatic lending should in the
            future adhere more closely to the annual budget cycle, with
            stronger internal controls to ensure rigorous preparation,
            and implementation; and, c)future sector dialogue should
            build on improving cost recovery, and the structure of road
            user charges.
